InterfaceSVGClipPathElement.name: SVGClipPathElement
InterfaceSVGClipPathElement.summary: The SVGClipPathElement interface provides access to the properties of <clipPath> elements, as well as methods to manipulate them.
InterfaceSVGClipPathElement.title: SVGClipPathElement

InterfaceSVGMaskElement.name: SVGMaskElement
InterfaceSVGMaskElement.summary: The SVGMaskElement interface provides access to the properties of <mask> elements, as well as methods to manipulate them.
InterfaceSVGMaskElement.title: SVGMaskElement

the-clip-path.name: clip-path
the-clip-path.summary: The clip-path CSS property creates a clipping region that sets what part of an element should be shown. Parts that are inside the region are shown, while those outside are hidden.

ie.notes: Internet Explorer only supports clip paths defined by url().

the-clip-path.title: clip-path

the-clip-path.name: clip-path
the-clip-path.summary: The clip-path presentation attribute defines or associates a clipping path with the element it is related to.
the-clip-path.title: clip-path

the-mask-clip.name: mask-clip
the-mask-clip.summary: The mask-clip CSS property determines the area which is affected by a mask. The painted content of an element must be restricted to this area.
the-mask-clip.title: mask-clip

the-mask-composite.name: mask-composite
the-mask-composite.summary: The mask-composite CSS property represents a compositing operation used on the current mask layer with the mask layers below it.

chrome.notes: See also -webkit-mask-composite for a similar non-standard property that uses different keywords.

chrome_android.notes: See also -webkit-mask-composite for a similar non-standard property that uses different keywords.

opera.notes: See also -webkit-mask-composite for a similar non-standard property that uses different keywords.

opera_android.notes: See also -webkit-mask-composite for a similar non-standard property that uses different keywords.

safari.notes: See also -webkit-mask-composite for a similar non-standard property that uses different keywords.

safari_ios.notes: See also -webkit-mask-composite for a similar non-standard property that uses different keywords.

samsunginternet_android.notes: See also -webkit-mask-composite for a similar non-standard property that uses different keywords.

webview_android.notes: See also -webkit-mask-composite for a similar non-standard property that uses different keywords.

edge_blink.notes: See also -webkit-mask-composite for a similar non-standard property that uses different keywords.

the-mask-composite.title: mask-composite

the-mask-image.name: mask-image
the-mask-image.summary: The mask-image CSS property sets the image that is used as mask layer for an element.

chrome.notes: From version 8, Chrome added support for gradient values. Initially, Chrome supported only -webkit- prefixed values for gradients (such as -webkit-linear-gradient()). Later, support for unprefixed values was added.

chrome_android.notes: From version 8, Chrome added support for gradient values. Initially, Chrome supported only -webkit- prefixed values for gradients (such as -webkit-linear-gradient()). Later, support for unprefixed values was added.

safari.notes: Initially, Safari supported only -webkit- prefixed values for gradients (such as -webkit-linear-gradient()). Later, support for unprefixed values was added.

safari_ios.notes: Initially, Safari supported only -webkit- prefixed values for gradients (such as -webkit-linear-gradient()). Later, support for unprefixed values was added.

webview_android.notes: Initially, Android supported only -webkit- prefixed values for gradients (such as -webkit-linear-gradient()). Later, support for unprefixed values was added.

edge_blink.notes: From version 8, Chrome added support for gradient values. Initially, Chrome supported only -webkit- prefixed values for gradients (such as -webkit-linear-gradient()). Later, support for unprefixed values was added.

the-mask-image.title: mask-image

the-mask-mode.name: mask-mode
the-mask-mode.summary: The mask-mode CSS property sets whether the mask reference defined by mask-image is treated as a luminance or alpha mask.
the-mask-mode.title: mask-mode

the-mask-origin.name: mask-origin
the-mask-origin.summary: The mask-origin CSS property sets the origin of a mask.
the-mask-origin.title: mask-origin

the-mask-position.name: mask-position
the-mask-position.summary: The mask-position CSS property sets the initial position, relative to the mask position layer set by mask-origin, for each defined mask image.
the-mask-position.title: mask-position

the-mask-repeat.name: mask-repeat
the-mask-repeat.summary: The mask-repeat CSS property sets how mask images are repeated. A mask image can be repeated along the horizontal axis, the vertical axis, both axes, or not repeated at all.
the-mask-repeat.title: mask-repeat

the-mask-size.name: mask-size
the-mask-size.summary: The mask-size CSS property specifies the sizes of the mask images. The size of the image can be fully or partially constrained in order to preserve its intrinsic ratio.
the-mask-size.title: mask-size

the-mask-type.name: mask-type
the-mask-type.summary: The mask-type CSS property sets whether an SVG <mask> element is used as a luminance or an alpha mask. It applies to the <mask> element itself.
the-mask-type.title: mask-type

the-mask.name: mask
the-mask.summary: The mask CSS shorthand property hides an element (partially or fully) by masking or clipping the image at specific points.

chrome.notes: While the property is recognized, values applied to it don't have any effect.
The prefixed property can be used with SVG and HTML with a slightly different syntax, which allows setting the non-standard -webkit-mask-attachment property.

chrome_android.notes: While the property is recognized, values applied to it don't have any effect.
The prefixed property can be used with SVG and HTML with a slightly different syntax, which allows setting the non-standard -webkit-mask-attachment property.

firefox.notes: From Firefox 10, the default color space when handling masks is sRGB. Previously, the default and only supported color space was linear RGB. This changes the appearance of mask effects, but brings Firefox into compliance with the second edition of the SVG 1.1 specification.

firefox_android.notes: From Firefox 10, the default color space when handling masks is sRGB. Previously, the default and only supported color space was linear RGB. This changes the appearance of mask effects, but brings Firefox into compliance with the second edition of the SVG 1.1 specification.

The prefixed property can be used with SVG and HTML with a slightly different syntax, which allows setting the non-standard -webkit-mask-attachment property.

opera_android.notes: While the property is recognized, values applied to it don't have any effect.
The prefixed property can be used with SVG and HTML with a slightly different syntax, which allows setting the non-standard -webkit-mask-attachment property.

The prefixed property can be used with SVG and HTML with a slightly different syntax, which allows setting the non-standard -webkit-mask-attachment property.

the-mask.title: mask

the-mask.name: mask
the-mask.summary: The mask attribute is a presentation attribute mainly used to bind a given <mask> element with the element the attribute belongs to.
the-mask.title: mask

clip-property.name: clip
clip-property.summary: The clip attribute is a presentation attribute defining the visible region of an element.
clip-property.title: clip

ClipPathElement.name: clipPath
ClipPathElement.summary: The <clipPath> SVG element defines a clipping path, to be used by the clip-path property.
ClipPathElement.title: <clipPath>

MaskElement.name: mask
MaskElement.summary: The <mask> element defines an alpha mask for compositing the current object into the background. A mask is used/referenced using the mask property.
MaskElement.title: <mask>

element-attrdef-mask-x.name: x
element-attrdef-mask-x.summary: The x attribute defines a x-axis coordinate in the user coordinate system.
element-attrdef-mask-x.title: x

element-attrdef-mask-y.name: y
element-attrdef-mask-y.summary: The y attribute defines a y-axis coordinate in the user coordinate system.
element-attrdef-mask-y.title: y
